actions.text: Referred to House Committee on The Judiciary.
For Previous Action See H.R.5129.
Committee Consideration and Mark-up Session Held.
Ordered to be Reported (Amended).
Reported to House (Amended) by House Committee on The Judiciary. Report No: 97-624.
Placed on Union Calendar No: 383.
Called up by House Under Suspension of Rules.
Considered by House Unfinished Business Vote Postponed Until July 20, 1982.
Passed House (Amended) by Yea-Nay Vote: 396 - 9 (Record Vote No: 189).
Received in the Senate and read twice and referred to the Committee on Judiciary.
Senate Committee on Judiciary discharged by Unanimous Consent.
Placed on Senate Legislative Calendar under Regular Orders. Calendar No. 744.
S.UP.AMDT.1261
S.UP.AMDT.1261
Considered by Senate.
Passed Senate in lieu of S. 1446 with an amendment by Voice Vote.
House Agreed to Senate Amendment 001 by Unanimous Consent.
House Concurred, in Senate Amendments 003, 005, 008 , with Amendments by Unanimous Consent.
House Disagreed to Senate Amendments 002, 004, 006, 007 by Unanimous Consent.
Senate concurred in House amendments to Senate amendments No. 3, 5, and 8. By Voice Vote.
Senate receded from its amendments Nos. 2, 4, 6 and 7 by Voice Vote.
Cleared for White House.
Measure Signed in Senate.
Presented to President.
Signed by President.
Became Public Law No: 97-351.

official_title: A bill to amend title 18 of the United States Code to implement the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, and for other purposes.
short_title: Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material Implementation Act of 1982

summary.text: (Measure passed Senate, amended) Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material Implementation Act of 1982 - Amends the Federal criminal code to establish penalties for: (1) intentionally possessing or transferring nuclear material which the offender knows is likely to cause or which in fact does cause, death or serious injury to any person or substantial damage to property; and (2) stealing, embezzling, or threatening to use any such material, or attempting or conspiring to do so. Provides for specific penalties for violations of this Act consisting of fines of not more than $250,000 and imprisonment for not more than 20 years except where the offender knowingly causes death or manifests extreme indifference to the life of an individual that results in death or serious bodily injury. Prescribes an indefinite term or life imprisonment in the latter case.
